February 21, 1922.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter with reference to writing a
“History of Yellow Fever” was received yesterday.
I am sure that you understand we are eager to have
you undertake the task; and that you know Mr. Rose
and the International Health Board well enough to
feel confident that the question of compensation
will be settled to suit the needs of the situation.
Mr. Rose would not want you to feel obliged to
“unduly press” yourself, as you express it, in order
to get material assembled before leaving Washington;
he would much prefer to have you take your time and
arrange, if necessary, to live in Washington as long
as you needed to be near the sources of information
that are available there and nowhere else.

Assistant Surgeon General H.R. Carter,
February 21, 1922.

We hope you will become absorbed in the work
by the end of the month! Please feel free to let us
know at any time if you would like a monthly stipend to
be provided.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Florence M. Read Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
